Curves

The world has a lot of curves: algebraic curves, rational curves, curved toenails, and Curves Women's Health and Fitness Club. Curves are occasionally useful: for example, the bell curve measures the distribution of human intelligence, and I flatter myself to say that my well-developed mind lies atop its very peak.

What are curves?

So anyways, what are curves?

Definition. Different people will tell you different things about curves: pure mathematicians, applied mathematicians, that one gym dude whose vocabulary consists of the word "gains" and nothing else, and spacetime-studying physicists when in the presence of your mom. But for the purpose of this course, a curve is the parametric equation

x=ψ(t)\mathbf{x} = \psi(t)x=ψ(t)

where x\mathbf{x}x is a vector representing a point on the curve, and ttt is a parameter that varies along the curve.

Remarks.

  1. Intuitively, this definition tells us that a curve is one-dimensional - it has only length but no width or depth. Of course, the curve may exist in multi-dimensional space, but it only has one parameter ttt that varies as you ride along its valleys and peaks.
  2. Pure mathematicians define a curve to be a mapping from a parameter ttt to a set of points on the curve. Corrupt mathematicians take their paychecks at the end of every month and don't ask questions. (Applied mathematicians define a curve to be the set of points itself rather than the mapping that maps to that set of points).
  3. A curve can be parametrized in more than one way. For example, x2+y2=1x^2 + y^2 = 1x2+y2=1 can be parametrized as (cos⁡t,sin⁡t)(\cos t, \sin t)(cost,sint) or as the slightly more unhinged
(x,y)=(1−t21+t2,2t1+t2)(x,y)= (\frac{1-t^2}{1+t^2}, \frac{2t}{1+t^2})(x,y)=(1+t21−t2​,1+t22t​)

(why would you do this?)

Classification of curves

Definition. A simple curve is a curve that does not intersect or touch itself (except at the endpoints, in which case it is simple and closed). A closed curve is a curve whose initial point corresponds with its endpoint, i.e. if the curve x=ψ(t)\mathbf{x = \psi}(t)x=ψ(t) is defined over the range a<b<ta < b < ta<b<t only, then ψ(a)=ψ(b)\psi(a) = \psi(b)ψ(a)=ψ(b). A preda-curve is a curve which touches other curves without their consent.

Definition. A curve is smooth if its derivative exists at every point; a curve is piecewise smooth if it can be divided into a finite number of smooth curves; and a curve is awkward if it struggles to strike up conversations with other curves.

Length of a simple curve

Suppose that x\mathbf{x}x is a simple curve defined by x=ψ(t)\mathbf{x} = \psi(t)x=ψ(t) within the range ta<t<tbt_a < t < t_bta​<t<tb​. A rigorous definition of the length of the curve is given as follows:

Definition. Length of a simple curve.

Let a partition of the interval ta<t<tbt_a < t < t_bta​<t<tb​ into NNN smaller intervals be given by (t0,t1),(t1,t2),...,(tN−1,tN)(t_0, t_1), (t_1, t_2), ..., (t_{N-1}, t_N)(t0​,t1​),(t1​,t2​),...,(tN−1​,tN​), in which ta=t0<t1<t2<...<tN=tbt_a = t_0 < t_1 < t_2 < ... < t_N = t_bta​=t0​<t1​<t2​<...<tN​=tb​. This partition also partitions the curve itself into NNN smaller intervals

(ψ(t0),ψ(t1)),(ψ(t1),ψ(t2)),...,(ψ(tN−1,ψ(tN)))(\psi(t_0), \psi(t_1)), (\psi(t_1), \psi(t_2)), ..., (\psi(t_{N-1}, \psi(t_N)))(ψ(t0​),ψ(t1​)),(ψ(t1​),ψ(t2​)),...,(ψ(tN−1​,ψ(tN​)))

where joining the endpoints of each intervals yields NNN lines inscribed within the curve:

The combined length of the lines provide a discrete approximation for the actual length of the curve, the accuracy of which improves as the number of partitions NNN is increased. Denote the total length of the NNN lines over a partition DDD as

lD=∑i=1N∣ψ(ti)−ψ(ti−1)∣l_D = \sum_{i=1}^N |\psi(t_i) - \psi(t_{i-1})|lD​=i=1∑N​∣ψ(ti​)−ψ(ti−1​)∣

indicating the Euclidean distance, and thus define the length of the curve x=ψ(t)\mathbf{x} = \psi(t)x=ψ(t) as

sup⁡DlD,\sup_{D} l_D,Dsup​lD​,

where sup⁡\supsup, pronounced 'sup (as in, "'sup, homeslice?"), denotes the maximum value lDl_DlD​ can attain over all possible DDD. In essence, if DDD partitions the curve into infinitely small pieces, then the discrete approximation becomes continuous reality and lDl_DlD​ as defined equals the actual length of the curve; this can be better represented by

Theorem. Integral representation of the arc length of a curve. Let x=ψ(t), ta<t<tb\mathbf{x} = \psi(t),\ t_a < t < t_bx=ψ(t), ta​<t<tb​ be the curve above. Then the arc length of the curve from t1t_1t1​ to t2t_2t2​, with ta<t1<t2<tbt_a < t_1 < t_2 < t_bta​<t1​<t2​<tb​, is given by the integral

∫t1t2∣ψ′(t)∣ dt\int_{t_1}^{t_2} |\psi'(t)|\ dt∫t1​t2​​∣ψ′(t)∣ dt

where ∣ψ′(t)∣|\psi'(t)|∣ψ′(t)∣ denotes the norm. Further denote the length of the curve from its starting point tat_ata​ to some ttt as

s(t)=∫tat∣ψ′(t)∣ dts(t) = \int_{t_a}^{t} |\psi'(t)|\ dts(t)=∫ta​t​∣ψ′(t)∣ dt

as above.

Proof.

Proceed from the discrete approximation of the curve length given above. Suppose that the curve lies in nnn-dimensional space, represented by the point

(x1(t),x2(t),...,xn(t))(x_1(t), x_2(t), ..., x_n(t))(x1​(t),x2​(t),...,xn​(t))

when its parameter equals ttt. The length of any subsection (ψ(ti−1),ψ(ti))(\psi(t_{i-1}), \psi(t_{i}))(ψ(ti−1​),ψ(ti​)) is given by ∣ψ(ti)−ψ(ti−1)∣|\psi(t_i) - \psi(t_{i-1})|∣ψ(ti​)−ψ(ti−1​)∣; if ψ(t)∈Rn\psi(t) \in \mathbb{R^n}ψ(t)∈Rn for some nnn, it is also given by the expression

∣Δψ∣=Δx12+Δx22+...+Δxn2|\Delta \psi| = \sqrt{\Delta x_1^2 + \Delta x_2^2 + ... + \Delta x_n^2}∣Δψ∣=Δx12​+Δx22​+...+Δxn2​​

for changes in x1,x2,...,xnx_1, x_2, ..., x_nx1​,x2​,...,xn​ from ψ(ti−1)\psi(t_{i-1})ψ(ti−1​) to ψ(ti)\psi(t_i)ψ(ti​), representing the Euclidean distance between the start and end points of the interval. When the interval becomes infinitesimal, we have

∣dψ∣=dx12+dx22+...+dxn2|d\psi| = \sqrt{dx_1^2 + dx_2^2 + ... + dx_n^2}∣dψ∣=dx12​+dx22​+...+dxn2​​

or, dividing by dtdtdt,

∣dψdt∣dt=(dx1dt)2+(dx2dt)2+...+(dxndt)2 dt|\frac{d\psi}{dt}| dt = \sqrt{(\frac{dx_1}{dt})^2 + (\frac{dx_2}{dt})^2 + ... + (\frac{dx_n}{dt})^2}\ dt∣dtdψ​∣dt=(dtdx1​​)2+(dtdx2​​)2+...+(dtdxn​​)2​ dt

where the sum of all such expressions from infinitesimal divisions of the curve over some range t1t_1t1​ to t2t_2t2​ yields the length of the curve along that range. Such a sum is given by an integral over that range, as defined by the Riemann sum (more later):

s(t)=∫tat∣dψdt∣ dt=s(t)=∫tat∣ψ′(t)∣ dts(t) = \int_{t_a}^{t} |\frac{d\psi}{dt}|\ dt = s(t) = \int_{t_a}^{t} |\psi'(t)|\ dts(t)=∫ta​t​∣dtdψ​∣ dt=s(t)=∫ta​t​∣ψ′(t)∣ dt

as desired. Note the fact that

dsdt=∣ψ′(t)∣\frac{ds}{dt} = |\psi'(t)|dtds​=∣ψ′(t)∣

regardless of the parameterization ψ\psiψ and ttt used.

Remarks.

  1. Call a curve with finite arc length rectifiable.
  2. If ψ\psiψ is not a simple curve but can be sub-divided into a finite number of simple curves, then the length of ψ\psiψ is the sum of the lengths of the simple curves.
  3. The arc length function s(t)s(t)s(t) as defined above is an increasing function; dsdt≥0\frac{ds}{dt} \geq 0dtds​≥0.
  4. An arc-length parametrization of the curve x=ψ(t)\mathbf{x} = \psi(t)x=ψ(t), denoted x=r(s)\mathbf{x = r}(s)x=r(s), maps the arc length of the curve to a point on the curve which has the corresponding arc length. For instance, while x=ψ(t)\mathbf{x} = \psi(t)x=ψ(t) gives the position of a point on the curve with respect to time, e.g. "I am five minutes down the road", x=r(s)\mathbf{x} = r(s)x=r(s) gives the position with respect to distance travelled, e.g. "I am five meters inside your house".

    The arc length parameterization can be obtained through the inverse function of s(t)s(t)s(t), denoted λ\lambdaλ:
t=λ(s(t))t = \lambda(s(t))t=λ(s(t))

...which always exists as s(t)s(t)s(t) is increasing with respect to ttt (and is thus one-to-one). This yields x=ψ(λ(s))=r(s)\mathbf{x} = \psi(\lambda(s)) = \mathbf{r}(s)x=ψ(λ(s))=r(s); such a parameterization is beneficial because it is an intrinsic quality of the curve independent on the path taken.

Proposition. The arc length parameterization satisfies

∣drds∣=1|\frac{d\mathbf{r}}{ds}| = 1∣dsdr​∣=1

which seems like a baffling result, but in reality just says "the rate of change of the arc length with respect to the arc length is 1", as ∣drds∣|\frac{dr}{ds}|∣dsdr​∣ is the magnitude of the rate of change of position (and thus the distance travelled along the curve, and thus the arc length).

Proof via the chain rule.

First, we have

r(s)=ψ(t)=ψ(λ(s))\mathbf{r}(s) = \psi(t) = \psi(\lambda(s))r(s)=ψ(t)=ψ(λ(s))

for some parameterization of the curve ψ(t)\psi(t)ψ(t), with λ(s)=t\lambda(s) = tλ(s)=t. Thus

dλds=dtds=1(dsdt)=1∣ψ′(t)∣\frac{d\lambda}{ds} = \frac{dt}{ds} = \frac{1}{(\frac{ds}{dt})} = \frac{1}{|\psi'(t)|}dsdλ​=dsdt​=(dtds​)1​=∣ψ′(t)∣1​

from above; as such

drds=(drdt)(dsdt)=ψ′(t)∣ψ′(t)∣\frac{d\mathbf{r}}{ds} = \frac{(\frac{d\mathbf{r}}{dt})}{(\frac{ds}{dt})} = \frac{\psi'(t)}{|\psi'(t)|}dsdr​=(dtds​)(dtdr​)​=∣ψ′(t)∣ψ′(t)​

as r(s)=ψ(t)\mathbf{r}(s) = \psi(t)r(s)=ψ(t) and so drdt=dψdt\frac{d\mathbf{r}}{dt} = \frac{d\psi}{dt}dtdr​=dtdψ​. Thus drds\frac{d\mathbf{r}}{ds}dsdr​ has unit length.

Tangents to curves

Definition. The tangent to a curve x=ψ(t)\mathbf{x} = \psi(t)x=ψ(t) at the point with parameter ttt is given by the line joining the points ψ(t)\psi(t)ψ(t) and ψ(t+h)\psi(t+h)ψ(t+h) as h→0h \to 0h→0.

Remark. The line joining ψ(t)\psi(t)ψ(t) and ψ(t+h)\psi(t+h)ψ(t+h) has direction vector

ψ(t+h)−ψ(t)h\frac{\psi(t+h) - \psi(t)}{h}hψ(t+h)−ψ(t)​

the limit of which as h→0h \to 0h→0 equals ψ′(t)\psi'(t)ψ′(t) if it exists and is nonzero.

This implies that

Theorem. The tangent vector to ψ(t)\psi(t)ψ(t) at point ttt is given by ψ′(t)\psi'(t)ψ′(t); the tangent vector of unit magnitude is given by ψ′(t)∣ψ′(t)∣\frac{\psi'(t)}{|\psi'(t)|}∣ψ′(t)∣ψ′(t)​.

If the arc length parameterization of the curve is used, its derivative with respect to its parameter always has magnitude one, and thus

Theorem. If the arc length parameterization of the curve is used, the rate of change of the position of the curve with respect to arc length

r′(s)=r′(s(t))=drds\mathbf{r}'(s) = \mathbf{r}'(s(t)) = \frac{d\mathbf{r}}{ds}r′(s)=r′(s(t))=dsdr​

is the unit tangent vector to the curve at all points.

Curvature, Normal, and Bi-normal

Curvature

Definition. A parameterization of the curve x=r(t)\mathbf{x} = r(t)x=r(t) is considered smooth if r′(t)r'(t)r′(t) is continuous and nonzero at every point on the curve. If the curve x\mathbf{x}x has a smooth parameterization, then it is a smooth curve.

If r′(t)r'(t)r′(t) is indeed zero at some point, the position of the curve does not change even if we travel along the path of the curve; as such the path is not smooth, and the curve will have sharp corners, cusps or discontinuities. For smooth curves without discontinuities, we define

Definition. The curvature of a smooth curve x=r(t)\mathbf{x} = r(t)x=r(t) is defined as the magnitude of the rate of change of its unit tangent vector with respect to arc length:

κ=∣dTds∣\kappa = |\frac{d\mathbf{T}}{ds}|κ=∣dsdT​∣

where T\mathbf{T}T is the unit tangent vector to the curve at ttt, given above by the derivative of the arc length parameterization with respect to arc length.

Curvature can be understood as how sharp a curve changes direction at a given point; if it heads in roughly the same direction in a region its unit tangent vector will change very little, corresponding with low curvature, and if it suddenly changes direction at a point the magnitude of the rate of change of the unit tangent vector will be significant, corresponding to a high curvature.

Note that we can rewrite the above with respect to ttt via the chain rule, for a curve parameterized by ϕ(t)\phi(t)ϕ(t):

κ=∣(dTdt)(dsdt)∣=∣T′(t)ϕ′(t)∣\kappa = |\frac{(\frac{d\mathbf{T}}{dt})}{(\frac{ds}{dt})}| = |\frac{\mathbf{T}'(t)}{\mathbf{\phi}'(t)}|κ=∣(dtds​)(dtdT​)​∣=∣ϕ′(t)T′(t)​∣

as ϕ(t)\mathbf{\phi}(t)ϕ(t) is the position of a point on the curve with respect to ttt, and so ϕ′(t)\mathbf{\phi}'(t)ϕ′(t) is the rate of change of that position (and thus the magnitude of the rate of change of the arc length).

Example. Find the curvature of a circle with radius aaa.

Solution.

Parameterize the circle as the curve x=r(t)=(acos⁡t,asin⁡t)\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{r}(t) = (a \cos t, a \sin t)x=r(t)=(acost,asint), yielding

r′(t)=(−asin⁡t,acos⁡t), ∣r′(t)∣=a.\mathbf{r}'(t) = (-a\sin t, a \cos t),\ |\mathbf{r}'(t)| = a.r′(t)=(−asint,acost), ∣r′(t)∣=a.

The unit vector to r(t)r(t)r(t) is given by

T(t)=r′(t)∣r′(t)∣=(−asin⁡t,acos⁡t)a=(−sin⁡t,cos⁡t)T(t) = \frac{r'(t)}{|r'(t)|} = \frac{(-a\sin t, a\cos t)}{a} = (-\sin t, \cos t)T(t)=∣r′(t)∣r′(t)​=a(−asint,acost)​=(−sint,cost)

with

T′(t)=(−cos⁡t,−sin⁡t)T'(t) = (-\cos t, -\sin t)T′(t)=(−cost,−sint)

and thus

κ=∣(−cos⁡t,−sin⁡t)a∣=1a\kappa = |\frac{(-\cos t, -\sin t)}{a}| = \frac{1}{a}κ=∣a(−cost,−sint)​∣=a1​

at all points ttt.

Normal and bi-normal

Definition. A normal vector N(t)N(t)N(t) to the curve x=r(t)\mathbf{x} = r(t)x=r(t) at point ttt is such that N(t)N(t)N(t) is perpendicular to the unit tangent T(t)T(t)T(t) at ttt.

Many normal vectors exist at any given point, but in particular

Theorem. For a curve r(t)r(t)r(t) and its unit tangent vector T(t)T(t)T(t), a normal vector at ttt is given by T′(t)T'(t)T′(t) (and its corresponding unit normal vector N^\hat{N}N^ by T′(t)∣T′(t)∣)\frac{T'(t)}{|T'(t)|})∣T′(t)∣T′(t)​).

Proof.

By virtue of T(t)T(t)T(t) being a unit vector, we have T(t)⋅T(t)=1T(t) \cdot T(t) = 1T(t)⋅T(t)=1. Suppose that the components of TTT are denoted TiT_iTi​; using summation convention results in

(T(t)⋅T(t))′=(Ti2)′=2TiTi′=(1)′=0(T(t) \cdot T(t))' = (T_i^2)' =2T_iT_i' = (1)' = 0(T(t)⋅T(t))′=(Ti2​)′=2Ti​Ti′​=(1)′=0

and thus TiTi′=T(t)⋅T′(t)=0T_i T_i' = T(t) \cdot T'(t) = 0Ti​Ti′​=T(t)⋅T′(t)=0, implying orthogonality.

Correspondingly define

Definition. The binormal vector to r(t)r(t)r(t) at ttt, denoted B(t)B(t)B(t), is also a normal vector to r(t)r(t)r(t), but is normal to both the normal and tangent vectors:

B(t)=T(t)×N(t).B(t) = T(t) \times N(t).B(t)=T(t)×N(t).

Thus the binormal, normal, and tangent vectors form a

Definition. Moving trihedral: a right-handed coordinate system of three unit vectors, all mutually orthogonal, formed around a point ttt on curve r(t)r(t)r(t).

Later on these vectors will be used to define an osculating plane; "osculating" is derived from the Latin root "osculatus", meaning "to kiss". This is drawn from the fact that the bi-normal vector is "kissing" the normal vector, and reminds me of how I am still bi-myself.

All of this allows us to define a much more efficient formula for curvature:

Theorem. The curvature of a curve parameterized by x=r(t)\mathbf{x = r}(t)x=r(t) at a point ttt is given by

κ=∣r′(t)×r′′(t)∣∣r′(t)∣3\kappa = \frac{|\mathbf{r}'(t) \times \mathbf{r}''(t)|}{|\mathbf{r}'(t)|^3}κ=∣r′(t)∣3∣r′(t)×r′′(t)∣​

Proof.

From

κ=∣T′(t)∣∣r′(t)∣\kappa = \frac{|\mathbf{T}'(t)|}{|\mathbf{r}'(t)|}κ=∣r′(t)∣∣T′(t)∣​

and (being careful to note that ∣r′(t)∣|r'(t)|∣r′(t)∣ is not a constant!)

T′(t)=(r′(t)∣r′(t)∣)′=(r′(t)s′(t))′=r′′(t)s′(t)−r′(t)s′′(t)s′(t)2=r′′(t)−T(t)s′′(t)s′(t)=r′′(t)−r′(t)∣r′(t)∣s′′(t)∣r′(t)∣=r′′(t)r′(t)−r′(t)s′′(t)∣r′(t)∣2\begin{aligned} \mathbf{T}'(t) = (\frac{r'(t)}{|r'(t)|})' &= (\frac{r'(t)}{s'(t)})' \\ &= \frac{r''(t)s'(t) - r'(t)s''(t)}{s'(t)^2} \\ &= \frac{r''(t) - T(t)s''(t)}{s'(t)} \\ &= \frac{r''(t) - \frac{r'(t)}{|r'(t)|}s''(t)}{|r'(t)|} \\ &= \frac{r''(t)r'(t) - r'(t) s''(t)}{|r'(t)|^2} \end{aligned}T′(t)=(∣r′(t)∣r′(t)​)′​=(s′(t)r′(t)​)′=s′(t)2r′′(t)s′(t)−r′(t)s′′(t)​=s′(t)r′′(t)−T(t)s′′(t)​=∣r′(t)∣r′′(t)−∣r′(t)∣r′(t)​s′′(t)​=∣r′(t)∣2r′′(t)r′(t)−r′(t)s′′(t)​​

using T(t)=r′∣r′∣T(t) = \frac{r'}{|r'|}T(t)=∣r′∣r′​. This also gives (from the second line)

r′′(t)=T′(t)s′(t)+T(t)s′′(t)r''(t) = T'(t)s'(t) + T(t)s''(t)r′′(t)=T′(t)s′(t)+T(t)s′′(t)

and (from T(t)=r′s′T(t) = \frac{r'}{s'}T(t)=s′r′​)

r′(t)=T(t)s′(t)r'(t) = T(t)s'(t)r′(t)=T(t)s′(t)

yielding

∣r′(t)×r′′(t)∣=∣s′(t)∣2∣(T×T′)∣=∣r′(t)∣2∣(T×T′)∣|r'(t) \times r''(t)| = |s'(t)|^2 |(T\times T')| = |r'(t)|^2|(T\times T')|∣r′(t)×r′′(t)∣=∣s′(t)∣2∣(T×T′)∣=∣r′(t)∣2∣(T×T′)∣

as T×T=0T \times T = 0T×T=0 by property of the cross product. As shown above, TTT and T′T'T′ are orthogonal, so their cross product has magnitude

∣T×T′∣=∣T∣∣T′∣sin⁡θ=∣T′∣=∣r′(t)×r′′(t)∣∣r′(t)∣2\begin{aligned} |T \times T'| &= |T||T'|\sin \theta \\ &= |T'| \\ &= \frac{|r'(t) \times r''(t)|}{|r'(t)|^2} \end{aligned}∣T×T′∣​=∣T∣∣T′∣sinθ=∣T′∣=∣r′(t)∣2∣r′(t)×r′′(t)∣​​

as TTT is a unit vector, and the last line originates from above. Recall that curvature is defined

∣T′(t)∣∣r′(t)∣\frac{|T'(t)|}{|r'(t)|}∣r′(t)∣∣T′(t)∣​

which finally equals

∣r′(t)×r′′(t)∣∣r′(t)∣3\frac{|r'(t) \times r''(t)|}{|r'(t)|^3}∣r′(t)∣3∣r′(t)×r′′(t)∣​

as desired.

Osculating planes

Not to be confused with oscillating plane, which was New York's local weather forecast on the morning of 9/11/2001, or ovulating crane, which is what I affectionately refer to my mother-in-law as, the osculating plane of a curve is defined as

Definition. The osculating plane of a curve r(t)r(t)r(t) at point ttt is the plane (uniquely) determined by the tangent and normal vectors T(t)T(t)T(t) and N(t)N(t)N(t) defined above.

Alternatively, the osculating plane results from the following limiting definition:

Proposition. Suppose that t−h,t,t+ht-h, t, t+ht−h,t,t+h represent three points on a curve r(t)r(t)r(t); a plane is uniquely determined obtained by the two vectors joining the points (r(t−h),r(t))(r(t-h),r(t))(r(t−h),r(t)) and r(t),r(t+h)r(t), r(t+h)r(t),r(t+h). The osculating curve to r(t)r(t)r(t) at ttt is thus given when h→0h \to 0h→0.

Proof (or at least a desperate justification).

From the above definition we know that the osculating curve contains the tangent and normal vectors, which are in the directions r′(t)r'(t)r′(t) and r′′(t)r''(t)r′′(t) respectively.

When h→0h \to 0h→0 as above, the vector joining r(t)r(t)r(t) and r(t+h)r(t+h)r(t+h) has direction

lim⁡h→0r(t+h)−r(t)h=r′(t)\lim_{h\to 0}\frac{r(t+h)-r(t)}{h} = r'(t)h→0lim​hr(t+h)−r(t)​=r′(t)

which is the tangent to r(t)r(t)r(t) at ttt; furthermore the plane also contains the vector in the direction

lim⁡h→0r(t)−r(t−h)h\lim_{h \to 0}\frac{r(t)-r(t-h)}{h}h→0lim​hr(t)−r(t−h)​

which is also r′(t)r'(t)r′(t). If the plane contains both vectors, however, it must contain the difference of the two vectors; which is

lim⁡h→0r(t+h)−2r(t)+r(t−h)h\lim_{h \to 0}\frac{r(t+h)-2r(t)+r(t-h)}{h}h→0lim​hr(t+h)−2r(t)+r(t−h)​

which, by definition, equals r′′(t)r''(t)r′′(t) and is thus in the direction of N(t)N(t)N(t).

As the tangent vector to a curve indicates its direction and the normal vector indicates the direction it bends/curves in (as it is in the direction T′(t)T'(t)T′(t)), the osculating plane is the plane that most closely touches the curve:

As previously stated, the binormal vector is simultaneously perpendicular to the unit normal and unit tangent vectors; and thus it is the normal vector to the osculating plane.

Theorem. The normal vector to the osculating plane at ttt for a curve r(t)r(t)r(t) is given by

r′(t)×r′′(t)∣r′(t)×r′′(t)∣\frac{r'(t) \times r''(t)}{|r'(t)\times r''(t)|}∣r′(t)×r′′(t)∣r′(t)×r′′(t)​

Note that r′(t)×r′′(t)r'(t)\times r''(t)r′(t)×r′′(t) is never zero because the two are perpendicular, aside from when r′′(t)r''(t)r′′(t) is itself zero.

Proof. The normal vector arises from N(t)×B(t)N(t) \times B(t)N(t)×B(t), which are in the direction of r′′(t)r''(t)r′′(t) and r′(t)r'(t)r′(t) respectively. Normalizing the vector leads to the above result.

Further define

Definition. The normal plane to the curve, uniquely defined by the normal and binormal vectors B(t)B(t)B(t) and N(t)N(t)N(t) at a point ttt; it contains all vectors normal to the curve at ttt.

Serret-Frenet equations

The Serret-Frenet equations concisely restate our above conclusions about curves. They are chiefly concerned with the arc length parameterization r(s)r(s)r(s) of a curve, and provide relationships between tangent, normal, and binormal vectors.

The arc length parameterization make these expressions more natural given that the tangent vector r′(s)r'(s)r′(s) is a unit vector. Denote this unit vector by u\mathbf{u}u; as proven previously, the curvature

κ=∣r′(t)×r′′(t)∣∣r′(t)∣3=∣r′′(s)∣≥0\kappa = \frac{|r'(t)\times r''(t)|}{|r'(t)|^3} = |r''(s)| \geq 0κ=∣r′(t)∣3∣r′(t)×r′′(t)∣​=∣r′′(s)∣≥0

when ∣r′(s)∣=1|r'(s)| = 1∣r′(s)∣=1. This yields the first Serret-Frenet equation:

Theorem. First Serret-Frenet equation: tangent and normal.

d2rds2=duds=κp\frac{d^2\mathbf{r}}{ds^2} = \frac{d\mathbf{u}}{ds} = \kappa\mathbf{p}ds2d2r​=dsdu​=κp

Where u\mathbf{u}u is the unit tangent vector and p\mathbf{p}p is the principal normal vector at sss, which exists if ∣r′′(s)∣>0|r''(s)|>0∣r′′(s)∣>0. It is a unit vector due to the above definition of curvature.

This is the same result as the one proven above. As before, define the binormal vector as the vector perpendicular to both the unit normal and tangent vectors; for the arc length parameterization it conveniently equals

b=u×p∣u×p∣=r′(s)×r′′(s)∣r′′(s)∣=r′(s)×r′′(s)κ\mathbf{b} = \frac{\mathbf{u \times p}}{|\mathbf{u\times p}|} = \frac{\mathbf{r'(s) \times r''(s)}}{|\mathbf{r}''(s)|} = \frac{\mathbf{r'(s)\times r''(s)}}{\kappa}b=∣u×p∣u×p​=∣r′′(s)∣r′(s)×r′′(s)​=κr′(s)×r′′(s)​

as above. Curvature is useful especally in physical scenarios, such as calculating forces, moments, or the total testicular torsion resulting from a spicy kick to the crotch. This leads us to

Theorem. Second Serret-Frenet equation: torsion. For unit binormal vector b\mathbf{b}b and principal normal vector p\mathbf{p}p, both functions of sss, we have

dbds=−τp\frac{d\mathbf{b}}{ds} = -\tau \mathbf{p}dsdb​=−τp

where τ\tauτ denotes the torsion.

Proof As b\mathbf{b}b is a unit vector, we have

b⋅b′=0\mathbf{b} \cdot \mathbf{b}' = 0b⋅b′=0

which was previously proven with the derivative of the unit tangent vector. However, as p⋅b\mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{b}p⋅b is also zero due to the binormal vector being perpendicular to the normal vector, p\mathbf{p}p and b′\mathbf{b}'b′ are in the same direction excepting a sign; this results in

dbds=−τp.\frac{d\mathbf{b}}{ds} = -\tau \mathbf{p}.dsdb​=−τp.

The intuition behind torsion originates from the fact that the binormal vector represents the unit normal vector to the osculating plane; thus, the rate at which the osculating plane "twists" and changes is given by dbds\frac{d\mathbf{b}}{ds}dsdb​ - and measured by the parameter τ\tauτ.

Finally, we have

Theorem. The Third Serret-Frenet equation describes the vanishing magnitude of my will to live. It represents the derivative of the principal normal vector as a linear combination of curvature, torsion, tangent, and binormal:

dpds=τb−κu\frac{d\mathbf{p}}{ds} = \tau\mathbf{b} - \kappa \mathbf{u}dsdp​=τb−κu

Proof. By definition of the unit binormal we have b×u=∣b∣∣u∣p=p\mathbf{b \times u} = |\mathbf{b}||\mathbf{u}|\mathbf{p} = \mathbf{p}b×u=∣b∣∣u∣p=p because both ∣b∣|\mathbf{b}|∣b∣ and ∣u∣|\mathbf{u}|∣u∣ are 111, and p\mathbf{p}p is orthogonal to both vectors. Thus

dpds=dds(b×u)=dbds×u+bduds=−τ(p×u)+κ(b×p)=τb−κu\begin{aligned} \frac{d\mathbf{p}}{ds} &= \frac{d}{ds}(\mathbf{b \times u}) \\ &= \frac{d\mathbf{b}}{ds}\times \mathbf{u} + \mathbf{b}\frac{d\mathbf{u}}{ds} \\ &= -\tau(\mathbf{p} \times \mathbf{u}) + \kappa (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{p}) \\ &= \tau \mathbf{b} - \kappa \mathbf{u} \end{aligned}dsdp​​=dsd​(b×u)=dsdb​×u+bdsdu​=−τ(p×u)+κ(b×p)=τb−κu​

making use of the cross-product derivative rule and the properties of the moving trihedral.

Alternative forms of writing the Serret-Frenet equation involve either the cross-product properties of the three vectors (e.g. dbds=−τ(b×u)\frac{d\mathbf{b}}{ds} = -\tau(\mathbf{b \times u})dsdb​=−τ(b×u)) or the following matrix representation:

[u′b′p′]=[00κ00−τ−κτ0][ubp]\begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{u}' \\ \mathbf{b}' \\ \mathbf{p}' \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & \kappa \\ 0 & 0 & -\tau \\ -\kappa & \tau & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{u} \\ \mathbf{b} \\ \mathbf{p} \end{bmatrix}⎣⎡​u′b′p′​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​00−κ​00τ​κ−τ0​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​ubp​⎦⎤​

which is skew-symmetric. The values for curvature and torsion κ\kappaκ and τ\tauτ contain the full scope of information for the geometry of a curve, excepting its position in space and its rotational angle; simultaneously, the moving trihedral of vectors b,u\mathbf{b, u}b,u and p\mathbf{p}p have important physical significance in various system modelled by curves, e.g. velocity, acceleration and speed.
